facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 39 and 92 of 1969 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights under Article 19(1).

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 39 92 of 1969. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by MATHEW, J.

anchor.surface_text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by MATHEW, J. These are petitions filed under article 32 of the Constitution praying for issue of appropriate direction or order for the enforcement of the fundamental right of the petitioners under article 19(1) of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner is a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913 with registered office in Calcutta and branch office at Binani House, Khundi Katra, Mirzapur, U.P.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913. It has its registered office in Calcutta and a branch office at Binani House, Khundi Katra, Mirzapur, U.P.

facts.text: Petitioner is an importer and dealer in non-ferrous metals like zinc, lead, copper, tin, etc. and is on the approved list of registered suppliers to DGSD.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is an importer and a dealer in number-ferrous metals like zinc, lead, companyper, tin, etc. and is on the approved list of registered suppliers to the Directorate General of Supplies and Disposals, hereinafter referred to as DGSD.

facts.text: Petitioner registered dealer in West Bengal under Bengal Finance Act, 1941 and Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It is also a registered dealer in the State of West Bengal under the Bengal Finance Act, 1941 and the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

facts.text: Import of non-ferrous metals under Open General Licence till June 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The import of number-ferrous metals was under Open General Licence till June 30, 1957. Thereafter, a licensing systems was introduced by the Government of India

facts.text: Government of India promulgated Non-Ferrous Metals Control Order, 1958 on April 2, 1958 under Essential Commodities Act, 1951 banning free sale of copper.

anchor.surface_text: On April 2, 1958, the Government of India promulgated the Non-Ferrous Metals Control Order, 1958 under the Essential Commodities Act, 1951 by virtue of which free sale of companyper was banned.

facts.text: Any import of copper by established licence holders distributed under directions of Controller of Nonferrous Metals.

anchor.surface_text: Any import of companyper by the established licence holders was to be distributed under the directions of the Controller of Nonferrous Metals.

facts.text: Established importers including petitioner not free to sell imported metals even to DGSD without additional import licence.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Non-Ferrous Metals Control Order, 1958. and also under the Import Trade Regulations, the established importers were number free to sell the metals imported by them against their quota licences even to the DGSD.

facts.text: Established importers obtained quota licences for import upto April 1964-March 1965, imports distributed under directions of Controller or Import Trade Control Authority.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Import Trade Control Policy, the established importers including the petitioner obtained quota licences for import of number-ferrous metals for the licensing period upto April, 1964-March, 1965,

facts.text: Government of India promulgated Scarce Industrial Materials Control Order, 1965 on September 14, 1965 under Defence of India Rules, freezing stocks of non-ferrous metals including incoming imports; repealed Non-Ferrous Metals Control Order 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1965, the Government of India promulgated the Scarce Industrial Materials Control Order, 1965, under the Defence of India Rules. Stocks of number-ferrous metals including incoming imports were thus frozen. The Non- Ferrous Metals Control Order, 1958, was repealed.

facts.text: Scarce Industrial Materials Control Order, 1965 repealed on June 6, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The Scarce Industrial Materials Control Order, 1965 was also repealed on June 6, 1966.

facts.text: Petitioner had been importing and supplying non-ferrous metals to respondents 1, 2 and 3 during the last 19 years.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had been importing and supplying number-ferrous metals to respondents 1, 2 and 3 during the last 19 years.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 agreed to pay and was paying Central Sales Tax or West Bengal Sales Tax as applicable per contract.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 had agreed to pay and was paying the Central Sales Tax and or West Bengal Sales Tax whichever was applicable to the petitioner in terms of the companytract.

facts.text: In 1966, Supreme Court in K.G. Khosla and Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes held that sale to DGSD of axle-box bodies manufactured in Belgium occasioned movement in course of import, no sales tax under s.5(2) CST Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In 1966, this Court held in K.G. Khosla and Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1  hereinafter. referred to as the Khosla Case, that the sale by Khosla Co. to DGSD in India of axle-box bodies manufactured in Belgium by their principal occasioned the movement of goods in companyrse of import

facts.text: Based on Khosla judgment, Respondent No. 2 issued Annexure P-1 order to authorities including Respondent No. 4 directing no sales tax allowance for supplies specifically imported against licences issued on DGSD Import Recommendation Certificates.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of this judgment, respondent No. 2 issued an order.  Annexure P-1  to all the authorities companycerned including respondent No. 4, namely, the Pay and Accounts Officer, Ministry of Works, Housing and Supply directing that sales tax should number be allowed in respect of supply of stores which has been specifically imported against licences

facts.text: Pay and Accounts Officer (Respondent 4) deducted Rs. 60,780/- from petitioner's pending bills acting on Annexure P-1.

anchor.surface_text: The Pay and Accounts Officer, acting on Annexure P-1 deducted the amounts of sales tax paid by the respondents under all the old companytracts from the current bills which were submitted by the petit ioner to him. Respondent No. 4 actually deducted a sum of Rs. 60,780/-

facts.text: Respondent 4 threatened to recover Rs. 2,35,130/- being sales tax already paid by Respondent 2 on executed contracts.

anchor.surface_text: from the bills which were pending payment and also threatened to recover Rs. 2,35,130-01 being the amount paid by respondent No. 2 as sales tax in respect of  1  1966 3 S.C.R. 352. companytracts which had, already been executed.

facts.text: Assessments on petitioner up to year ending October 27, 1962 completed prior to Khosla judgment and Annexure P-1.

anchor.surface_text: The assessments on the petitioner upto the year ending October, 27, 1962, were companypleted prior to the date of judgment in Khosla Case and the issue of the order at Annexure P-1.

facts.text: Petitioner filed revised returns with West Bengal Sales Tax authorities claiming refund of taxes paid, treating sales to DGSD as in course of import per Khosla.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, when it came to know of Annexure P-1 Order, approached the Sales Tax authorities in West Bengal and filed revised returns in the pending assessments and claimed refund of taxes paid on the sales, treating the sales as having been made in the companyrse of import

facts.text: West Bengal Sales Tax authorities held two sales involved: foreign seller to petitioner and petitioner to DGSD; no privity between DGSD and foreign sellers; petitioner entitled to import from any source; no obligation to supply DGSD post-import; tax exigible on petitioner's sales.

anchor.surface_text: The West Bengal Sales Tax authorities took the view that there were two sales involved in the transactions in question, namely, sale to the petitioner by the foreign sellers and sale by the petitioner to the DGSD, that there was numberprivity of companytract between the DGSD and the foreign sellers, that the petitioner, under the import licences granted to it, was entitled to import the goods from any person or companyntry and that the import licences issued as against the companytracts with the DGSD imposed numberobligation on the petitioner to supply the goods to the DGSD after they had been imported. They, therefore, held that tax was exigible on the sales by the petitioner to the DGSD.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that sales to DGSD did not occasion movement of goods in course of import; separate from purchase contracts with foreign sellers; Khosla not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the petitioner that the transactions in question, namely, the sales which the petitioner made to DGSD were number the sales which occasioned the movement of the goods in the companyrse of import and as those sales were separate and distinct from the companytracts of purchase made by the petitioners with the foreign sellers which alone occasioned the movement of goods in the companyrse of import, tax was exigible upon the transactions of sale by the petitioner to DGSD and, therefore, the decision in Khosla Case has numberapplication to facts here.

facts.text: Central Government contended that contracts with DGSD envisaged import; DGSD recommendation for import licences; thus sales to DGSD occasioned import.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the Central Government that the companytracts of sale between the petitioner and the DGSD envisaged the import of goods for fulfilling the companytracts and it was for that reason that there was first the recommendation for issue of import licences by DGSD and then the actual issue of import licences

facts.text: Court held no obligation on DGSD to procure import licences; petitioner responsible to obtain licences; sales to DGSD did not occasion import; movement occasioned by petitioner's purchase contracts with foreign sellers; no privity between DGSD and foreign sellers.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberprivity of companytract between DGSD and the foreign sellers. The foreign sellers did number enter into any companytract by themselves or through the agency of the petitioner to the DGSD and the movement of goods from the foreign companyntries was number occasioned on account of the sales by the petitioner to DGSD.

facts.text: Court distinguished case from Khosla and Coffee Board cases, holding petitioner's sales to DGSD taxable.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason in principle to distinguish this case from the decision in the Coffee Board Case though that case was companycerned with the question when a sale occasions the movement of goods in the companyrse of export.

issues.text: Whether the sales by the petitioner to the DGSD are in the course of import so as to be exempt from tax under Article 286(1)(b) and section 5(2) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the petitioner that the transactions in question, namely, the sales which the petitioner made to DGSD were not the sales which occasioned the movement of the goods in the course of import and as those sales were separate and distinct from the contracts of purchase made by the petitioners with the foreign sellers which alone occasioned the movement of goods in the course of import, tax was exigible upon the transactions of sale by the petitioner to DGSD and, therefore, the decision in Khosla Case has no application to facts here. Article 286 1 b provides

arguments.claim: The sales by the petitioner to DGSD were not the sales which occasioned the movement of goods in the course of import; they were separate from purchase contracts with foreign sellers which occasioned the import; tax is exigible; Khosla case has no application

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the petitioner that the transactions in question, namely, the sales which the petitioner made to DGSD were not the sales which occasioned the movement of the goods in the course of import and as those sales were separate and distinct from the contracts of purchase made by the petitioners with the foreign sellers which alone occasioned the movement of goods in the course of import, tax was exigible upon the transactions of sale by the petitioner to DGSD and, therefore, the decision in Khosla Case has no application to facts here.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court held that movement was occasioned by petitioner's purchase contracts with foreign sellers, not sales to DGSD; no privity; distinguished Khosla

arguments.claim: Contracts of sale between petitioner and DGSD envisaged import of goods; DGSD recommendation for import licences; thus sales to DGSD occasioned movement in course of import
arguments.court_reasoning: No obligation on DGSD to procure licences; petitioner's obligation to obtain them; recommendation not imperative; contracts envisaging import does not mean sales occasion import

arguments.claim: There were two sales: foreign seller to petitioner, petitioner to DGSD; no privity between DGSD and foreign sellers; petitioner entitled to import from any source; no obligation to supply DGSD post-import; tax exigible on petitioner's sales

anchor.surface_text: The West Bengal Sales Tax authorities took the view that there were two sales involved in the transactions in question, namely, sale to the petitioner by the foreign sellers and sale by the petitioner to the DGSD, that there was no privity of contract between the DGSD and the foreign sellers, that the petitioner, under the import licences granted to it, was entitled to import the goods from any person or country and that the import licences issued as against the contracts with the DGSD imposed no obligation on the petitioner to supply the goods to the DGSD after they had been imported. They, therefore, held that tax was exigible on the sales by the petitioner to the DGSD.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court adopted similar reasoning: no privity, movement by purchase contracts, sales separate

arguments.claim: Sales tax should not be allowed on supplies specifically imported against licences issued on DGSD Import Recommendation Certificates, per Khosla case

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of this judgment, respondent No. 2 issued an order. Annexure P-1 to all the authorities concerned including respondent No. 4, namely, the Pay and Accounts Officer, Ministry of Works, Housing and Supply directing that sales tax should not be allowed in respect of supply of stores which has been specifically imported against licences issued by the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports on the basis of Import Recommendation Certificates issued by the DGSD

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the other. In State of Travancore Cochin Others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory and Others  1 , it was observed by the same learned Chief Justi

arguments.court_reasoning: Khosla not applicable to facts; sales did not occasion import

arguments.claim: A sale occasions import only if it occasions the movement or effected by transfer of title before customs frontier, per s.5(2) CST Act

anchor.surface_text: And, in s.5(2) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, Parliament has given a legislative meaning to the expression 'sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of the import of the goods into the territory of India' only if the sale or purchase either occasions such import or is effected by a transfer of documents of title to the goods before the goods have crossed the customs frontiers of India.

arguments.claim: Petitioner's sales to DGSD did not occasion import; movement occasioned by separate purchase contracts with foreign sellers; no privity between DGSD and foreign sellers
Case analogous to Coffee Board case; introduction of intermediary (petitioner) breaks the link between sale and import
In Khosla, contract with DGSD directly led to import from Belgium; here, petitioner acts as principal buying separately; thus distinguishable
Integrated activities doctrine: sale and import must be parts of single transaction; cannot dissociate

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, C.J. said that a sale by export involves a series of integrated activities commencing from the agreement of sale with a foreign buyer and ending with the delivery of the goods to a common carrier for transport out of the country by land or sea and that such a sale cannot be dissociated from the export without which it cannot be effectuated, and the sale and resultant export form parts of a single transaction.

arguments.claim: No bond between sales to DGSD and actual import; petitioner free to source from anywhere; like Ben Gorm case

anchor.surface_text: This Court found nothing in the transaction from which a bond could be said to spring between the sale and the intended export linking them as parts of the same transaction. The sellers had no concern with the export, the sale imposed or involved no obligation to export

holdings.text: No movement of goods in the course of import took place in pursuance to the contracts of sale made by the petitioner with the DGSD. The petitioners sales to DGSD were distinct and separate from his purchases from foreign sellers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Movement occasioned by petitioner's separate purchase contracts with foreign sellers, not sales to DGSD; applied s.5(2) CST test requiring sale to cause import.

holdings.text: the sales by the petitioner to the DGSD did not occasion the import. It was purchases made by the petitioner from the foreign sellers which occasioned the import of the goods.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of 'occasions such import' test under s.5(2) CST Act; sales separate transaction from import-causing purchases.

holdings.text: There was no privity of contract between DGSD and the foreign sellers. The foreign sellers did not enter into any contract by themselves or through the agency of the petitioner to the DGSD

anchor.surface_text: There was no privity of contract between DGSD and the foreign sellers. The foreign sellers did not enter into any contract by themselves or through the agency of the petitioner to the DGSD and the movement of goods from the foreign countries

holdings.reasoning_summary: No direct contractual link between buyer (DGSD) and foreign sellers; petitioner acted as principal, not agent.

holdings.text: the movement of goods from the foreign countries was not occasioned on account of the sales by the petitioner to DGSD.

anchor.surface_text: and the movement of goods from the foreign countries was not occasioned on account of the sales by the petitioner to DGSD. It was contended on behalf of the Central Government that the contracts of sale between the petitioner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly rejects that sales caused movement; distinguishes from integrated activities doctrine.

holdings.text: even if the contracts envisaged the import of goods and their supply to the DGSD from out of the goods imported, it did not follow that the movement of the goods in the course of import was occasioned by the contracts of sale by the petitioner with DGSD.
holdings.reasoning_summary: DGSD recommendation for licences not obligatory; petitioner's duty to obtain licences; envisaging import insufficient for 'occasions'.

holdings.text: We see no reason in principle to distinguish this case from the decision in the Coffee Board Case though that case was concerned with the question when a sale occasions the movement of goods in the course of export.

anchor.surface_text: We see no reason in principle to distinguish this case from the decision in the Coffee Board Case though that case was concerned with the question when a sale occasions the movement of goods in the course of export.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to Coffee Board: intermediary (petitioner) breaks chain between sale and movement; two separate sales.

holdings.text: Khosla Case has no application to facts here.

anchor.surface_text: and, therefore, the decision in Khosla Case has no application to facts here. Article 286 1 b provides 286. 1 No law of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Khosla on facts: there principal-agent relation with foreign manufacturer; here petitioner principal with separate purchases; no single sale occasioning import.

precedents.citation: K.G. Khosla and Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1 [1966 3 S.C.R. 352]

anchor.surface_text: In 1966, this Court held in K.G. Khosla and Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes 1  hereinafter. referred to as the Khosla Case, that the sale by Khosla Co. to DGSD in India of axle-box bodies manufactured in Belgium by their principal occasioned the movement of goods in companynse of import and sales tax was number exigible on the transaction in view of s. 5 2  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

precedents.case_name: K.G. Khosla and Co. v. Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes
precedents.cited_proposition: Sale to DGSD in India of goods manufactured abroad by principal occasioned movement of goods in course of import exempt from sales tax under s.5(2) Central Sales Tax Act
precedents.cited_holding: the sales took place in the companynse of import of goods within s.5 2  of the Act, and are, therefore, exempt from taxation

precedents.citation: State of Travancore Cochin Others v. The Bombay Co. Ltd. 1 [1952 S.C.R. 1112]

anchor.surface_text: In State of Travancore Cochin Others v. The Bombay Co. Ltd.  1  Patanjali Sastri, C.J. said that a sale by export involves a series of integrated activities companymencing from the agreement of sale with a foreign buyer and ending with the delivery of the goods to a companymon carrier for transport out of the companyntry by land or sea and that such a sale cannot be dissociated from the export without which it cannot be effectuated, and the sale and resultant export form parts of a single transaction.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Bombay Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: A sale by export involves integrated activities from agreement with foreign buyer to delivery to carrier, sale and export part of single transaction
precedents.cited_holding: sale and resultant export form parts of a single transaction. Of these two integrated activities which together companystitute an expert sale, whichever first occurs can well be regarded as taking place in the companynse of the other.

precedents.citation: State of Travancore Cochin Others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory and Others 1 [1954 S.C.R. 53,63]

anchor.surface_text: In State of Travancore Cochin Others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory and Others  1 , it was observed by the same learned Chief Justice that the phrase integrated activities was used in the previous decision to denote that such a sale  i.e. a sale which occasions the export cannot be dissociated from the export without which it cannot be effectuated, and the sale and the resultant export form parts of a single transaction and that it is in that sense that the two activities the sale and the export- were said to be integrated.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory
precedents.cited_proposition: Phrase 'integrated activities' denotes sale which occasions export cannot be dissociated from export; sale and export parts of single transaction
precedents.cited_holding: the phrase integrated activities was used in the previous decision to denote that such a sale i.e. a sale which occasions the export cannot be dissociated from the export without which it cannot be effectuated

precedents.citation: Ben Gorm Nilgiri Plantations Company V. Sales Tax Officer 2 [1964 7 S.C.R. 706]

anchor.surface_text: In Ben Gorm Nilgiri Plantations Company V. Sales Tax Officer 2 , the question was whether the sales of the tea chests at auctions held at Fort Cochin were exempt from levy of sales tax by virtue of article 286 1  b . The nature of the transaction was as follows A manufacture obtains from the Tea Board allotment of export quota, the manufacturer then puts the tea in chests which are sold in public auctions bids are made by agents or intermediaries of foreign buyers agents and intermediaries then obtain licences from the Central Government for export.

precedents.case_name: Ben Gorm Nilgiri Plantations Co. v. Sales Tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: To occasion export, bond between contract of sale and exportation such that each link inextricably connected; sale for export vs in course of export
precedents.cited_holding: to occasion export there must exist such a bond between the compantract of sale and the actual exportation, that each link is in extricably companynected with the one immediately preceding it and that without such a bond, a transaction of sale cannot be called a sale in the companynse of export of goods out of the territory of India.

precedents.citation: Coffee Board v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer 1 [1970 3 S.C.R. 147]

anchor.surface_text: In Coffee Board v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer  1 , hereinafter referred to as Coffee Board Case, the Coffee Board claimed that as certain sales of companyfee to registered exporters in March and April, 1963 were sales made in the companynse of export,it companyld number be taxed under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959. The rules framed by the Coffee Board provided that only dealers who had registered themselves as exporters of companyfee with the Coffee Board or their agents and who held permits from the Chief Coffee Marketing Officer in that behalf would be permitted to participate in the auction , and after the bidding companyes to an end, the payment of price would take place in a particular way.

precedents.case_name: Coffee Board v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: Sales by Coffee Board to export intermediaries not in course of export due to broken link by intermediary; only subsequent sale to foreign buyer occasions export
precedents.cited_holding: though the sales by the Coffee Board were sales for export, they were number sales in the companynse of export, that there were two independent sales involved in the export programme the first sale by the Coffee Board to the export promoter, and the second sale by the export promoter to a foreign buyer which occasioned the movement of goods

anchor.surface_text: No movement of goods in the course of import took place in pursuance to the contracts of sale made by the petitioner with the DGSD. The petitioners sales to DGSD were distinct and separate from his purchases from foreign sellers. To put it differently, the sales by the petitioner to the DGSD did number occasion the import. It was purchases made by the petitioner from the foreign sellers which occasioned the import of the goods. The purchases of the goods and import of the goods in pursuance to the contracts of purchases were, no doubt, for sale to the DGSD.

outcome.relief_summary: Sales by petitioner to DGSD did not occasion movement of goods in course of import; tax exigible; respondents not entitled to deduct Rs. 60,780/- or recover Rs. 2,35,130.01

anchor.surface_text: No movement of goods in the course of import took place in pursuance to the contracts of sale made by the petitioner with the DGSD. The petitioners sales to DGSD were distinct and separate from his purchases from foreign sellers. To put it differently, the sales by the petitioner to the DGSD did number occasion the import. It was purchases made by the petitioner from the foreign sellers which occasioned the import of the goods. The purchases of the goods and import of the goods in pursuance to the contracts of purchases were, no doubt, for sale to the DGSD.
